interestingcomments.content:
Question - How to truly learn to read light in different situations. /!/ Before you write anything about ISO, aperture, or shutter speed, save your fingers the effort in typing anything out. 

I understand the three main factors that go into taking pictures. The problem is that I have no freaking idea whether I'm exposed properly or not. I'm working with film. I'm using an Olympus 35RC without a battery. I just finished my first test roll of Ilford HP5 that i pushed to 800 in the camera.

I have NO IDEA of whether or not my shots were exposed properly or not. I tried sunny 16 for a couple shots, but I still don't trust the shots that weren't in open, direct sunlight.

So I need help. There are no real youtube videos that truly teach how to read light. Forest Hills Film Lab put out a decent one that went in to describe different situations of light (WHICH IS ACTUALLY IMPORTANT), but still didn't give a way to practice. 

I've heard Ansel Adam's book *The Negative* is a great source to learn the zone system, but I haven't really found any reviews for someone with my problem. 

Has anyone had this problem with shooting full manual without a light meter? Anyone learned what to do about it?
